title: Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in sections 30 to 38, the following amounts shall not be deducted in computing the income chargeable under the head 'Profits and gains of business or profession'

subsections.description: In the case of any assessee, the following amounts shall not be deducted:

items.description: Any interest, royalty, fees for technical services or other sum chargeable under this Act, which is payable outside India or in India to a non-resident, not being a company or to a foreign company, on which tax is deductible at source under Chapter XVII-B and such tax has not been deducted or, after deduction, has not been paid on or before the due date specified in sub-section (1) of section 139.
provisions: Where tax has been deducted in a subsequent year or deducted but paid after the due date, the sum shall be allowed as a deduction in the year when the tax is paid.

If tax is not deducted as per Chapter XVII-B but the assessee is not deemed to be in default under section 201, it shall be deemed that tax has been deducted on the date of furnishing the return by the payee.

items.description: Thirty percent of any sum payable to a resident, on which tax is deductible at source under Chapter XVII-B and such tax has not been deducted or, after deduction, has not been paid on or before the due date specified in sub-section (1) of section 139.
provisions: Where tax is deducted in a subsequent year or deducted but paid after the due date, thirty percent of such sum shall be allowed as a deduction in the year when the tax is paid.

If tax is not deducted as per Chapter XVII-B but the assessee is not deemed to be in default under section 201, it shall be deemed that tax has been deducted on the date of furnishing the return by the payee.

items.description: Any consideration paid or payable to a non-resident for a specified service on which equalisation levy is deductible under the provisions of Chapter VIII of the Finance Act, 2016, and such levy has not been deducted or after deduction, has not been paid on or before the due date specified in sub-section (1) of section 139.
provisions: Where the equalisation levy has been deducted in any subsequent year or has been deducted but paid after the due date, the sum shall be allowed as a deduction in the year when the levy is paid.

items.description: Any sum paid on account of fringe benefit tax under Chapter XIIH.
Any sum paid on account of any rate or tax levied on the profits or gains of any business or profession or assessed at a proportion of, or otherwise on the basis of, any such profits or gains.
explanations: The term 'tax' includes any surcharge or cess, by whatever name called, on such tax.
The sum paid on account of tax includes any sum eligible for relief under section 90 or section 91.

items.description: Any sum paid on account of wealth-tax.
items.explanation: Wealth-tax includes wealth-tax chargeable under the Wealth-tax Act, 1957, or any similar tax in any other country.

items.description: Any amount paid by way of royalty, licence fee, service fee, privilege fee, service charge or any other fee or charge levied exclusively on or appropriated by a State Government undertaking by the State Government.
Any payment which is chargeable under the head 'Salaries', if it is payable outside India or to a non-resident, and if the tax has not been paid thereon nor deducted therefrom under Chapter XVII-B.

Any payment to a provident or other fund established for the benefit of employees of the assessee, unless the assessee has made arrangements to ensure that tax is deducted at source from any payments made from the fund.
Any tax actually paid by an employer referred to in clause (10CC) of section 10.
In the case of any firm assessable as such, the following amounts shall not be deducted:
Any payment of salary, bonus, commission or remuneration to any partner who is not a working partner.
Any payment of remuneration or interest to any partner which is not authorised by, or is not in accordance with, the terms of the partnership deed.
Any payment of remuneration or interest to any partner authorised by the partnership deed, but which relates to any period before such partnership deed.
Any payment of interest to any partner, authorised by the partnership deed, but exceeding the amount calculated at twelve percent simple interest per annum.
Any payment of remuneration authorised by the partnership deed, but exceeding the specified limits based on the book-profit of the firm.
In the case of an association of persons or body of individuals, the following amounts shall not be deducted:
Any payment of interest, salary, bonus, commission or remuneration to a member of the association or body.

subsections.title: Expenses or payments not deductible in certain circumstances

subsections.text: The provisions of this section shall have effect notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in any other provision of this Act relating to the computation of income under the head 'Profits and gains of business or profession'.

clauses.text: Where the assessee incurs any expenditure in respect of which payment has been or is to be made to any person referred to in clause (b) of this sub-section, and the Assessing Officer is of opinion that such expenditure is excessive or unreasonable having regard to the fair market value of the goods, services or facilities for which the payment is made or the legitimate needs of the business or profession of the assessee or the benefit derived by or accruing to him therefrom, so much of the expenditure as is so considered by him to be excessive or unreasonable shall not be allowed as a deduction.
The persons referred to in clause (a) are the following:
items: where the assessee is an individual, any relative of the assessee;

where the assessee is a company, firm, association of persons or Hindu undivided family, any director of the company, partner of the firm, or member of the association or family, or any relative of such director, partner or member;
any individual who has a substantial interest in the business or profession of the assessee, or any relative of such individual;

a company, firm, association of persons or Hindu undivided family having a substantial interest in the business or profession of the assessee or any director, partner or member of such company, firm, association or family, or any relative of such director, partner or member or any other company carrying on business or profession in which the first mentioned company has substantial interest;

a company, firm, association of persons or Hindu undivided family of which a director, partner or member, as the case may be, has a substantial interest in the business or profession of the assessee; or any director, partner or member of such company, firm, association or family or any relative of such director, partner or member;

any person who carries on a business or profession, where the assessee being an individual, or any relative of such assessee, has a substantial interest in the business or profession of that person; or where the assessee being a company, firm, association of persons or Hindu undivided family, or any director of such company, partner of such firm or member of the association or family, or any relative of such director, partner or member, has a substantial interest in the business or profession of that person.

clauses.text: For the purposes of this sub-section, a person shall be deemed to have a substantial interest in a business or profession, if, in a case where the business or profession is carried on by a company, such person is, at any time during the previous year, the beneficial owner of shares carrying not less than twenty per cent of the voting power; and in any other case, such person is, at any time during the previous year, beneficially entitled to not less than twenty per cent of the profits of such business or profession.

subsections.text: Where the assessee incurs any expenditure in respect of which a payment or aggregate of payments made to a person in a day, otherwise than by an account payee cheque drawn on a bank or account payee bank draft, or use of electronic clearing system through a bank account or through such other electronic mode as may be prescribed, exceeds ten thousand rupees, no deduction shall be allowed in respect of such expenditure.

Where an allowance has been made in the assessment for any year in respect of any liability incurred by the assessee for any expenditure and subsequently during any previous year the assessee makes payment in respect thereof, otherwise than by an account payee cheque, bank draft, or prescribed electronic mode, the payment shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of business or profession and chargeable to income-tax as income of the subsequent year if the payment exceeds ten thousand rupees.

Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law or in any contract, where any payment in respect of any expenditure has to be made by an account payee cheque drawn on a bank or account payee bank draft or use of electronic clearing system, then the payment may be made by such cheque or draft or electronic clearing system, and no person shall be allowed to raise, in any suit or other proceeding, a plea based on the ground that the payment was not made in cash or in any other manner.

clauses.text: No deduction shall be allowed in respect of any provision made by the assessee for the payment of gratuity to his employees on their retirement or termination of employment.

Nothing in clause (a) shall apply in relation to any provision made by the assessee for the purpose of payment of a sum by way of any contribution towards an approved gratuity fund, or for the purpose of payment of any gratuity that has become payable during the previous year.

subsections.text: No deduction shall be allowed in respect of any sum paid by the assessee as an employer towards the setting up or formation of, or as contribution to, any fund, trust, company, association of persons, body of individuals, society registered under the Societies Registration Act, 1860, or other institution for any purpose, except where such sum is so paid for specific purposes provided by or under any other law.

subsections.title: Certain deductions to be only on actual payment
subsections.description: This section outlines deductions allowed only in the year in which the sum is actually paid, irrespective of the year in which the liability to pay was incurred.

a.description: Sum payable as tax, duty, cess, or fee under any law for the time being in force.

b.description: Employer's contribution to any provident, superannuation, or gratuity fund, or other employee welfare fund.

c.description: Sum referred to in clause (ii) of sub-section (1) of section 36.

d.description: Interest on loans from public financial institutions or state financial corporations.

da.description: Interest on loans from notified non-banking financial companies.

e.description: Interest on loans or advances from scheduled or co-operative banks.

f.description: Employer's payment for leave in lieu of employee leave balance.

g.description: Payment to Indian Railways for use of railway assets.

h.description: Payment to micro or small enterprises beyond the time limit specified in the MSME Development Act.

deduction_restriction.description: These deductions shall be allowed only in the year in which the sum is actually paid, not the year when the liability to pay is incurred.

h.description: Provisions do not apply for sums paid within due dates for filing the return of income, provided evidence is furnished.

explanations.text: If a deduction under clause (a) or (b) is allowed in a previous year, no further deduction will be allowed in the year the sum is actually paid.
The term 'any sum payable' refers to a sum incurred as liability in the previous year, even if not payable within that year.
If a deduction for sums under clauses (c) or (d) was allowed in an earlier year, no further deduction will be allowed in the year of actual payment.
For deductions under clause (e), similar restrictions apply for sums incurred in earlier years and paid in the current year.
For interest under clause (da), deductions are allowed only when the interest is actually paid, and deferred payments are not considered paid.
Interest under clause (e) is only deductible if actually paid; deferred payments are excluded.
Definitions of terms like 'public financial institutions', 'scheduled bank', etc., as referenced in the section.

subsections.title: Maintenance of accounts by certain persons carrying on profession or business.

1.description: Every person carrying on legal, medical, engineering, architectural profession, or the profession of accountancy, technical consultancy, interior decoration, or any other profession as notified by the Board shall maintain books of accounts and documents to enable the Assessing Officer to compute total income.

2.description: Every person carrying on business or profession (except professions referred to in sub-section 1) shall maintain books of accounts if:

conditions.condition: His income from business or profession exceeds one lakh twenty thousand rupees or his total sales, turnover or gross receipts exceed ten lakh rupees in any of the three preceding years.
In the case of a newly set up business, if income exceeds one lakh twenty thousand rupees or total sales, turnover or gross receipts exceed ten lakh rupees during that previous year.
Where profits and gains are deemed under section 44AE, 44BB, or 44BBB, and income claimed is lower than the deemed profits and gains.
Where section 44AD(4) applies, and income exceeds the maximum amount not chargeable to income tax.

clause_1.description: For individuals or Hindu undivided families, the limit for income is substituted to two lakh fifty thousand rupees.

clause_2.description: For individuals or Hindu undivided families, the limit for total sales, turnover or gross receipts is substituted to twenty-five lakh rupees.

3.description: The Board may, by rules, prescribe the books of account and other documents (including inventories, where necessary), the particulars to be contained, and the form and manner in which they shall be kept and maintained.

4.description: The Board may, by rules, prescribe the period for which the books of account and other documents should be retained.

subsections.title: Audit of accounts of certain persons carrying on business or profession.

a.description: Every person carrying on business shall get their accounts audited if their total sales, turnover or gross receipts exceed one crore rupees in any previous year.

conditions.condition: If aggregate of all amounts received, including sales, turnover, or gross receipts, in cash does not exceed 5% of the said amount.
If aggregate of all payments made, including expenditures, in cash does not exceed 5% of the said payment.

exceptions.description: In this case, the limit for 'one crore rupees' is substituted to 'ten crore rupees'.
For the purposes of this clause, a payment or receipt by cheque or bank draft not being account payee is considered as cash.

b.description: Every person carrying on profession shall get their accounts audited if their gross receipts in profession exceed fifty lakh rupees in any previous year.

c.description: Every person carrying on business shall get their accounts audited if profits and gains from business are deemed under section 44AE, 44BB, or 44BBB, and they claim income to be lower than the deemed profits or gains.

d.description: Every person carrying on profession shall get their accounts audited if profits and gains from the profession are deemed under section 44ADA and they claim income to be lower than the deemed profits, and their income exceeds the maximum amount not chargeable to income tax.

e.description: Every person carrying on business shall get their accounts audited if the provisions of sub-section (4) of section 44AD are applicable and income exceeds the maximum amount not chargeable to income tax.

audit_requirements.description: The person must get their accounts audited by an accountant before the specified date and furnish the audit report in the prescribed form duly signed and verified by the accountant.

exemptions.description: This section does not apply to a person who declares profits and gains under section 44AD(1) or 44ADA(1).
This section does not apply to a person deriving income under section 44B or 44BBA, from April 1, 1985, or the date the relevant section came into force.
If a person is required to get their accounts audited under any other law, it suffices to comply with this section by submitting the report as per that law before the specified date.

explanation.accountant: The term 'accountant' refers to the meaning under sub-section (2) of section 288.
explanation.specified_date: The specified date is one month prior to the due date for furnishing the return of income under sub-section (1) of section 139.

subsections.title: Special provision for computing profits and gains of business on presumptive basis.

1.description: In the case of an eligible assessee engaged in an eligible business, a sum equal to 8% of the total turnover or gross receipts of the assessee in the previous year on account of such business shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of such business chargeable to tax under the head 'Profits and gains of business or profession'.

exceptions.condition: If the total turnover or gross receipts are received by account payee cheque, account payee bank draft, or electronic clearing system, the rate of deemed profits shall be 6%.

2.description: Any deduction under sections 30 to 38 shall be deemed to have already been given full effect to, and no further deduction under those sections shall be allowed for the purposes of sub-section (1).

3.description: The written down value of any asset of an eligible business shall be deemed to have been calculated as if the assessee had claimed and been allowed the deduction in respect of depreciation for each relevant assessment year.

4.description: If an eligible assessee declares profits in accordance with this section but fails to do so for any of the next five assessment years, they shall not be eligible for the provisions of this section for the subsequent five assessment years.

5.description: If an eligible assessee's total income exceeds the maximum amount not chargeable to tax, they must maintain books of account as required under section 44AA(2), get the accounts audited, and furnish the audit report as per section 44AB.

6.description: The provisions of this section do not apply to:

exceptions.condition: A person carrying on profession as referred to in section 44AA(1).
A person earning income from commission or brokerage.
A person carrying on an agency business.

criteria: An individual, Hindu undivided family, or a partnership firm (except limited liability partnership firms as defined in section 2(n) of the LLP Act, 2008), who is a resident.
Has not claimed deduction under sections 10A, 10AA, 10B, 10BA, or under provisions of Chapter VIA under the heading 'C. Deductions in respect of certain incomes'.
Any business except plying, hiring, or leasing goods carriages under section 44AE.
Total turnover or gross receipts do not exceed two crore rupees in the previous year.
If amounts received in cash do not exceed 5% of the total turnover or gross receipts, the limit is increased to three crore rupees.

subsections.title: Special provision for computing profits and gains of profession on presumptive basis

subsections.text: Notwithstanding anything contained in sections 28 to 43C, in case of an assessee, being an individual or a partnership firm other than a limited liability partnership as defined under clause (n) of sub-section (1) of section 2 of the Limited Liability Partnership Act, 2008 (6 of 2009), who is a resident in India, and is engaged in a profession referred to in sub-section (1) of section 44AA and whose total gross receipts do not exceed fifty lakh rupees in a previous year, a sum equal to fifty per cent of the total gross receipts of the assessee in the previous year on account of such profession or, as the case may be, a sum higher than the aforesaid sum claimed to have been earned by the assessee, shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of such profession chargeable to tax under the head "Profits and gains of business or profession".

provisos.text: Provided that in case of an assessee where the amount or aggregate of the amounts received during the previous year, in cash, does not exceed five per cent of the total gross receipts of such previous year, this sub-section shall have effect as if for the words "fifty lakh rupees", the words "seventy-five lakh rupees" had been substituted.

Provided further that for the purposes of the first proviso, the receipt of amount or aggregate of amounts by a cheque drawn on a bank or by a bank draft, which is not account payee, shall be deemed to be the receipt in cash.

subsections.text: Any deduction allowable under the provisions of sections 30 to 38 shall, for the purposes of sub-section (1), be deemed to have been already given full effect to and no further deduction under those sections shall be allowed.

The written down value of any asset used for the purposes of profession shall be deemed to have been calculated as if the assessee had claimed and had been actually allowed the deduction in respect of the depreciation for each of the relevant assessment years.

Notwithstanding anything contained in the foregoing provisions of this section, an assessee who claims that his profits and gains from the profession are lower than the profits and gains specified in sub-section (1) and whose total income exceeds the maximum amount which is not chargeable to income-tax, shall be required to keep and maintain such books of account and other documents as required under sub-section (1) of section 44AA and get them audited and furnish a report of such audit as required under section 44AB.

subsections.title: Capital gains

sub_sections.description: Any profits or gains arising from the transfer of a capital asset effected in the previous year shall be chargeable to income-tax under the head 'Capital gains'.
Profits or gains arising from receiving money or assets under insurance due to damage or destruction of a capital asset.
Profits or gains arising from receiving an amount under a unit-linked insurance policy.
sub_sections.exemption: Clause (10D) of section 10 does not apply.

sub_sections.description: Profits or gains arising from conversion of a capital asset into stock-in-trade of a business.
Profits or gains arising from transfer of beneficial interest in securities.
Transfer of a capital asset to a firm or association of persons or body of individuals.
sub_sections.reference: Section 48 (value of capital asset in books of firm)

sub_sections.description: Capital gain arising from the reconstitution of specified entities.
conditions: C = fair market value of capital asset received
D = balance in capital account of specified person

sub_sections.description: Capital gain arising from transfer due to compulsory acquisition under any law.
Capital gain from the transfer of land/building under a specified agreement.
conditions: Certificate of completion by competent authority
exceptions: Exemption if transfer occurs before certificate issue

sub_sections.description: Capital gain arising from the repurchase of units referred to in section 80CCB.

subsections.title: Mode of Computation of Capital Gains

sub_sections.description: Expenditure incurred wholly and exclusively in connection with the transfer of the capital asset.
sub_sections.details: Deductions are allowed for any expenditure directly related to the transfer of the asset.

sub_sections.description: Cost of acquisition and the cost of improvement to the capital asset.
exclusions: Deductions claimed on interest under section 24(b) or Chapter VIA.

sub_sections.description: Income of specified entity attributable to the capital asset being transferred.
sub_sections.details: In case of transfer by a specified person from a specified entity under subsection (4) of section 45, the income chargeable to tax under that sub-section is deducted in the prescribed manner.

sub_sections.description: Capital gains for non-residents from shares or debentures of Indian companies.
sub_sections.details: Computation is done by converting cost of acquisition, transfer expenditure, and full value of consideration into foreign currency, and then reconverting it to Indian currency.

sub_sections.description: Indexed cost of acquisition and improvement for long-term capital gains.
sub_sections.details: Long-term capital gains are computed by using indexed cost of acquisition and improvement instead of actual cost for assets transferred after July 23, 2024.

sub_sections.description: Exclusion for specific long-term capital assets.
exceptions: Equity shares, units of equity-oriented funds, business trust units, bonds, and debentures excluding capital indexed bonds or Sovereign Gold Bonds.

sub_sections.description: Non-residents are exempt from capital gains arising from appreciation of the rupee against foreign currency on redemption of rupee-denominated bonds issued by Indian companies.
Market value for shares, debentures, or warrants transferred under a gift or irrevocable trust.
sub_sections.details: The market value on the date of transfer is considered as the full value of consideration.

sub_sections.description: No deduction is allowed for securities transaction tax under Chapter VII of the Finance (No. 2) Act, 2004.

explanations.foreign_currency: As defined in Section 2 of the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999.
explanations.indexed_cost_of_acquisition: The cost of acquisition, adjusted for inflation using the Cost Inflation Index of the relevant year and the year of acquisition.
explanations.indexed_cost_of_improvement: The cost of any improvement, adjusted similarly using the Cost Inflation Index.
explanations.cost_inflation_index: The index specified by the Central Government, calculated based on 75% of the rise in the Consumer Price Index for the immediately preceding year.

references: Cost Inflation Index Notifications by the Central Government

subsections.title: Special Provision for Computation of Capital Gains in Case of Depreciable Assets

sub_sections.description: Capital gains for transfer of assets forming part of a block of assets with depreciation.
sub_sections.details: If the total consideration received or accrued from the transfer of assets in a block exceeds the sum of specified amounts (expenditure, written down value, and cost of new assets acquired), the excess is deemed to be short-term capital gains.

sub_sections.description: Ceasing of block of assets due to transfer of all assets within the block.
sub_sections.details: When a block ceases to exist (all assets in the block are transferred), the cost of acquisition is the written down value at the beginning of the year, adjusted by the actual cost of assets acquired in the same year. The income from such transfer is deemed to be short-term capital gains.

sub_sections.description: Special provision for goodwill included in the block of assets for business or profession.
sub_sections.details: For assessment years starting on or after 1st April 2020, goodwill depreciation will follow special rules for determining the written down value and short-term capital gain.

explanations.goodwill_transfer: The reduction of the amount of goodwill from the block of assets, in accordance with Section 43, is deemed to be a transfer.

references: Section 2(42A) - Definition of short-term capital asset
Section 48 and 49 - Mode of computation and cost of acquisition

subsections.title: Profit on Sale of Property Used for Residence

sub_sections.description: Capital gains treatment on the transfer of a residential property.
sub_sections.details: If the capital gain arises from the transfer of a long-term capital asset (residential house), and the taxpayer (individual or Hindu undivided family) purchases or constructs a new residential house within specific time limits, then the capital gain will be treated as follows:

sub_sections.description: Capital gain greater than cost of new asset.
sub_sections.details: If the capital gain exceeds the cost of the new residential house, the difference is charged as income under section 45. For calculating capital gains from the transfer of the new asset within three years, the cost will be nil.

sub_sections.description: Capital gain less than or equal to the cost of new asset.
sub_sections.details: If the capital gain is equal to or less than the cost of the new residential house, no capital gain is charged under section 45. The cost of the new asset will be reduced by the amount of the capital gain for future transfer.

sub_sections.description: Option to purchase or construct two residential houses.
sub_sections.details: If the capital gain is less than two crore rupees, the assessee may opt to purchase or construct two residential houses. This option must be exercised before the transfer and applies as if the words 'one residential house' are replaced by 'two residential houses'. The option cannot be exercised in subsequent years.

sub_sections.description: Limitation on cost exceeding ten crore rupees.
sub_sections.details: If the cost of the new asset exceeds ten crore rupees, the amount exceeding ten crore will not be considered for the purpose of this section.

sub_sections.description: Deposit requirement if capital gain is not fully utilised.
sub_sections.details: If the capital gain is not used to purchase or construct the new asset within the specified period, the unutilized amount must be deposited in a specified account before the return is filed. If not used within the prescribed time, the unutilized amount will be charged as income under section 45.

sub_sections.description: Capital gain exceeding ten crore rupees not considered for deposit.
sub_sections.details: Capital gains exceeding ten crore rupees are not considered for the deposit requirement under this sub-section.

explanations.deposit_scheme: The deposited amount must be used for purchasing or constructing the new residential asset within the specified period. If not utilized, the amount will be charged as income and the taxpayer can withdraw the deposit as per the government scheme.

references: Section 45 - Capital gains chargeable to tax

subsections.title: Capital gain on transfer of capital assets not to be charged in certain cases

subsections.text: Where the capital gain arises from the transfer of a long-term capital asset before the 1st day of April, 1992, and the assessee has, within a period of six months after the date of such transfer, invested or deposited the whole or any part of the net consideration in any specified asset, the capital gain shall be dealt with as follows:

conditions.text: If the cost of the new asset is not less than the net consideration in respect of the original asset, the whole of such capital gain shall not be charged under section 45.

If the cost of the new asset is less than the net consideration in respect of the original asset, so much of the capital gain as bears the same proportion to the whole of the capital gain as the cost of acquisition of the new asset bears to the net consideration shall not be charged under section 45.

explanations.text: For the purposes of this sub-section, 'specified asset' means certain government securities, savings certificates, units of Unit Trust of India, equity shares, and certain other specified bonds and debentures depending on the date of the original asset transfer.
'Eligible issue of capital' shall have the meaning assigned to it in sub-section (3) of section 80CC.
An assessee shall not be deemed to have invested the whole or any part of the net consideration in equity shares unless specified conditions are met.
'Cost', in relation to any new asset, means the amount of such deposit.

'Net consideration', in relation to the transfer of a capital asset, means the full value of the consideration received or accruing from the transfer reduced by any expenditure incurred wholly and exclusively in connection with such transfer.

subsections.text: Where the assessee deposits after the 27th day of April, 1978, the whole or any part of the net consideration in respect of the original asset in any new asset, being a deposit referred to in sub-clause (vi) of clause (a) of Explanation 1, certain conditions must be fulfilled.
Where the conditions specified in sub-section (1A) are fulfilled, the assessee shall furnish a certificate from the relevant officer within a period of ninety days.

Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), where the capital gain arises from the transfer of the original asset after the 31st day of March, 1992, certain conditions regarding advance payments and investments must apply.

Where the new asset is transferred, or converted into money, within a period of three years from the date of its acquisition, the capital gain will be deemed to be income chargeable under the head 'Capital gains'.

explanations.text: Where an assessee takes any loan or advance on the security of a deposit after the 27th day of April, 1978, such deposit will be deemed to have been converted into money.
If an assessee takes a loan or advance on the security of a new asset, such new asset will be deemed to have been converted into money.

subsections.text: Where the cost of equity shares is taken into account for the purposes of clauses (a) or (b) of sub-section (1), a deduction with reference to such cost shall not be allowed under section 80CC.

subsections.heading: Capital gain on transfer of certain capital assets not to be charged in case of investment in residential house

applicability.asset_type: long-term capital asset (not being a residential house)

full_exemption.condition: Cost of new asset is at least equal to net consideration
full_exemption.result: Whole capital gain is not charged under section 45

partial_exemption.condition: Cost of new asset is less than net consideration
partial_exemption.result: Proportionate capital gain is not charged under section 45

ineligibility_conditions.own_multiple_houses: Assessee owns more than one residential house (other than new asset) at the time of transfer
ineligibility_conditions.purchase_other_house: Assessee purchases another residential house within one year after transfer
ineligibility_conditions.construct_other_house: Assessee constructs another residential house within three years after transfer
ineligibility_conditions.income_from_other_house: Income from other residential houses is chargeable under the head 'Income from house property'

net_consideration.definition: Full value of the consideration received from the transfer, reduced by transfer-related expenses

investment_period.purchase_time: Within 1 year before or 2 years after transfer

tax_implications.transfer_of_new_asset: If new asset is transferred within 3 years, the exempted capital gain is taxable in the year of transfer

deposit_of_unutilized_gain.condition: Unutilized capital gain must be deposited in specified bank account before filing return
deposit_of_unutilized_gain.action: If not used, the unutilized amount becomes taxable after 3 years

exemption_limit.excess_limit: Exemption not allowed for amounts exceeding Rs. 10 crore

adjusted.definition: The term 'adjusted' refers to the modified or updated value of a capital asset, which includes factors like improvements or costs incurred that affect the asset's value in the context of capital gains and acquisitions.

cost_of_improvement.definition: The cost of improvement is the expenditure incurred to add value to a capital asset. It includes capital expenditures made after the asset was acquired, but does not include expenses deductible under specific income categories like interest on securities, income from house property, etc.

specifics.goodwill_or_intangible_asset: For capital assets such as goodwill or any intangible asset of a business, the cost of improvement is considered nil.
specifics.before_2001_property: If the capital asset was owned by the previous owner or the assessee before April 1, 2001, the cost of improvement includes all capital expenditure made after that date to enhance the asset.
specifics.after_2001_property: For assets acquired after April 1, 2001, the cost of improvement refers to capital expenditure incurred by the assessee after the property became theirs, or by the previous owner if the property was transferred through modes outlined in Section 49.

cost_of_acquisition.definition: The cost of acquisition is the amount paid by the assessee to acquire a capital asset, and it varies based on the nature of the asset and how it was obtained.

specifics.goodwill_or_intangible_asset: For capital assets such as goodwill of a business, trademarks, or any rights related to manufacturing or business, the cost of acquisition is generally considered to be the purchase price if acquired from a previous owner, and nil in other cases.
specifics.capital_assets_before_2001: For assets acquired before April 1, 2001, the cost of acquisition can be either the purchase price or the fair market value of the asset as of April 1, 2001, as per the assessee’s option.

financial_assets.subscription_rights: If the assessee becomes entitled to subscribe to additional financial assets or is allotted additional assets, the cost of acquisition for the original asset is the amount paid for the original asset.
financial_assets.allotments_without_payment: For financial assets allotted to the assessee without payment, the cost of acquisition is considered to be nil.

specifics.demutualisation: For assets acquired under schemes like demutualisation, the cost of acquisition is related to the original membership of the exchange and may be treated as nil for trading or clearing rights.

subsections.title: Income from Other Sources
subsections.overview: Section 56 of the Income Tax Act, 1961, deals with the taxation of income arising from various sources not specifically covered under other sections. It primarily relates to income received as gifts, income from properties, or income from sources such as interest, dividends, and winnings.

sub_section_1.heading: Income from Other Sources
sub_section_1.description: Income of the nature described in this section, which is not chargeable under any other head, is included under the head 'Income from Other Sources'.
examples: Winnings from lotteries, gambling, or betting
Rent from properties not falling under 'House Property'

sub_section_2.heading: Gifts and Inheritances
sub_section_2.description: Section 56(2) specifies that certain gifts and inheritances are taxable under the head 'Income from Other Sources'.

gifts_received_from_non_relatives.taxable_limit: Gifts exceeding ₹50,000 in aggregate received from non-relatives during a year are taxable.
exceptions: Gifts received from specified relatives like parents, siblings, etc. are not taxable.
Any amount received on occasion of marriage or for inheritance is not taxable.

gifts_in_kind.taxable_value: If a gift is received in kind (e.g., immovable property, shares, etc.), the fair market value of the gift on the date of receipt is considered for taxation.

sub_section_3.heading: Winnings from Lottery, Gambling, or Betting
sub_section_3.description: Winnings from lottery, gambling, or betting are taxed under this section. The entire winnings are taxable as income.
sub_section_3.tax_rate: The rate of tax on winnings from lotteries, gambling, or betting is typically at a flat rate of 30% (without deduction of expenses).
sub_section_3.deductions: No deductions under other sections (like 80C, 80D) are allowed from winnings under this category.

sub_section_4.heading: Income from Other Sources
sub_section_4.description: This section also deals with various incomes that may not fall under specific heads like business or profession, but still form part of the total income. Examples include interest, rent, etc.

specific_incomes.taxable_when: Interest received from loans or fixed deposits is taxable under this head.
Income received as rent from properties other than those covered under 'House Property' is taxable under this section.

sub_section_5.heading: Taxability of Gifts
sub_section_5.description: Gifts received from non-relatives in excess of ₹50,000 are chargeable to tax under the head 'Income from Other Sources'.

exceptions.exemption_limit: Gifts received from relatives, or on the occasion of marriage, or from a will/inheritance, are exempt.

sub_section_6.heading: Taxation of Income from Property
sub_section_6.description: Income arising from properties such as land, buildings, or assets that are not covered under other heads (e.g., House Property) falls under 'Income from Other Sources'.

sub_section_7.heading: Income from Capital Assets
sub_section_7.description: Certain types of capital income (such as income from sale or transfer of capital assets that do not fall under capital gains) are included under this section.

sub_section_8.heading: Certain Specified Incomes
sub_section_8.description: Other specific sources of income such as income from sub-letting, royalties, etc., that are not directly covered elsewhere in the Act.

important_cases.summary: The court held that income from gifts is taxable under Section 56(2) when the value exceeds the exemption limit, unless it falls under specific exemptions.
The case clarified that winnings from a lottery, though considered as income, can only be taxed at the specified rate of 30%, without any deductions.

exemptions: Winnings from a lottery (subject to certain limits and taxes)
deductions: Deductions under 80C, 80D, etc., are not available on income under this head.

sub_section_10.heading: Special provisions for certain items of income
sub_section_10.description: Some specified incomes are treated differently, and specific rules or provisions apply for taxation.

sub_section_11.heading: Taxation of certain incomes as capital gains
sub_section_11.description: Income that could have been categorized as capital gains under specific circumstances, but is instead treated as income under this section, as per the provisions of the Act.

subsections.title: Amounts Not Deductible
subsections.overview: Section 58 outlines the specific expenses that cannot be deducted while computing income chargeable under the head 'Income from Other Sources'. This section restricts deductions for personal expenses, certain types of interest payments, and payments related to salaries, among others.

items.description: Any personal expenses of the assessee are not deductible.
Any expenditure of the nature referred to in sub-section (12) of section 40A is not deductible.

Any interest payable outside India (not being interest on a loan issued for public subscription before April 1, 1938), on which tax has not been paid or deducted under Chapter XVII-B, is not deductible.
Any salary payment chargeable under the head 'Salaries' that is payable outside India is not deductible, unless tax has been paid or deducted as per Chapter XVII-B.
[No deduction applicable under this item due to omission of section (iv)]

subsection_1A.heading: Application of Section 40
subsection_1A.description: The provisions of sub-clauses (ia) and (iia) of clause (a) of section 40 shall apply in computing income under the head 'Income from Other Sources', similar to their application under the head 'Profits and gains of business or profession'.

subsection_2.heading: Application of Section 40A
subsection_2.description: The provisions of section 40A shall apply in computing income under the head 'Income from Other Sources', similar to their application under the head 'Profits and gains of business or profession'.

subsection_3.heading: Provisions for Foreign Companies
subsection_3.description: For foreign companies, the provisions of section 44D shall apply in computing income under the head 'Income from Other Sources', similar to their application under the head 'Profits and gains of business or profession'.

subsection_4.heading: Expenditure on Lottery, Gambling, and Betting
subsection_4.description: No deduction shall be allowed for any expenditure or allowance in connection with income from lotteries, crossword puzzles, races (including horse races), card games, or any gambling or betting activities. However, this does not apply to income from the activity of owning and maintaining horses for running in horse races.

exemptions.activity: Owning and maintaining horses for horse races
exemptions.description: No deduction restrictions apply if the assessee is the owner of horses maintained for running in horse races.

definition.horse_race: A horse race upon which wagering or betting may be lawfully made.

subsections.title: Transfer of Income Where There is No Transfer of Assets
subsections.overview: Section 60 deals with the situation where a person transfers income arising from an asset, but there is no transfer of the actual asset itself. In such cases, the income is considered taxable in the hands of the transferor, even if the transfer is revocable or irrevocable.

main_provision.description: Any income arising to a person by virtue of a transfer (whether revocable or irrevocable) of income from an asset, but where there is no transfer of the underlying asset from which the income arises, will be treated as the income of the transferor.
main_provision.taxability: The income will be chargeable to income-tax as part of the transferor's total income, irrespective of the fact that the asset itself has not been transferred.

applicability.revocable_or_irrevocable: The provisions apply irrespective of whether the transfer is revocable or irrevocable, and whether the transfer took place before or after the commencement of the Income Tax Act.

example.scenario: A person may transfer the income arising from a property but retain ownership of the property itself. Even though the asset is not transferred, the income from the asset will be taxed in the hands of the original owner (transferor).

subsections.title: Revocable Transfer of Assets
subsections.overview: Section 61 deals with the taxability of income arising from a revocable transfer of assets. If the transfer is revocable, the income generated from such assets will be taxed in the hands of the transferor.

main_provision.description: Any income arising from a revocable transfer of assets will be considered as the income of the transferor. Such income shall be included in the transferor's total income and will be charged to income tax accordingly.
main_provision.taxability: The income is chargeable to income tax as part of the transferor’s income, even though the asset itself has been transferred on a revocable basis.

applicability.revocable_transfer: The section specifically applies in cases where the transfer of assets is revocable, meaning the transferor retains the right to revoke the transfer of the asset at any point in time.

example.scenario: A person transfers ownership of an asset to another individual but retains the right to revoke the transfer in the future. The income generated by this asset is taxed in the hands of the transferor, not the transferee, because the transfer is revocable.

subsections.title: Transfer and Revocable Transfer Defined
subsections.overview: Section 63 defines what constitutes a 'transfer' and a 'revocable transfer' for the purposes of Sections 60, 61, and 62, providing clarity on conditions under which a transfer may be considered revocable.

subsections.description: A transfer is deemed to be revocable if it meets any of the following conditions:

conditions.details: The transfer contains a provision for the re-transfer, directly or indirectly, of the whole or part of the income or assets to the transferor.
The transfer gives the transferor a right to re-assume power, directly or indirectly, over the whole or any part of the income or assets.

subsections.description: 'Transfer' is a broad term that includes any of the following:

example.scenario: If a person transfers assets to a trust but retains the right to re-assume control over the assets or their income, the transfer would be considered revocable under Section 63.

subsections.title: Income of Individual to Include Income of Spouse, Minor Child, etc.
subsections.overview: Section 64 outlines the provisions for including income arising directly or indirectly to the spouse, minor child, or other connected individuals in the total income of the individual for tax purposes.

subsections.description: Income arising to an individual from various sources, including spouse, son's wife, or others, is included in the individual’s total income, subject to specific conditions.

conditions.details: Income arising to the spouse of an individual from a concern in which the individual has a substantial interest is included in the individual's total income, with an exception if the spouse has technical or professional qualifications.
Income arising to the spouse from assets transferred by the individual to the spouse without adequate consideration is included in the individual’s total income.
Income arising to the son’s wife from assets transferred by the individual is included in the individual's total income.
Income arising to any person or association of persons from assets transferred by the individual for the benefit of the spouse is included in the individual's total income.
Income arising to any person or association of persons from assets transferred by the individual for the benefit of the son’s wife is included in the individual's total income.

subsections.description: Income of a minor child (excluding certain income based on work or skill) is included in the total income of the parent with the higher total income.

conditions.details: If the minor child earns income from manual work or application of skills, talent, or specialized knowledge, it is excluded from the parent's income.

subsections.description: If an individual transfers separate property to a Hindu Undivided Family (HUF) without adequate consideration, the income from the converted property is deemed to arise to the individual, not the family.

explanation.details: The term 'property' includes movable or immovable property, sale proceeds, and any money representing such property.
'Income' includes loss for the purposes of this section.

examples.scenario: If an individual transfers assets to his spouse without adequate consideration, the income from these assets is included in the individual's total income for tax purposes.
The income of a minor child from manual work or skill application is not included in the parent’s total income under Section 64(1A).

subsections.title: Set off of Loss from One Source Against Income from Another Source under the Same Head of Income
subsections.overview: Section 70 provides for the set-off of losses under different sources of income within the same head of income, and the treatment of losses in the case of capital assets.

subsections.description: Where the net result for any assessment year in respect of a source of income, other than 'Capital Gains', is a loss, the assessee is entitled to set off such loss against income from any other source under the same head of income.

conditions.head_of_income: Any head other than Capital Gains

subsections.description: In case of a short-term capital asset, if the result is a loss, the assessee is entitled to set off the loss against income from other capital assets, following computation under sections 48 to 55.

Where the result of computation in respect of any capital asset, other than a short-term capital asset, is a loss, the assessee is entitled to set off the loss against income from other capital assets (other than short-term assets).

examples.scenario: If an individual incurs a loss from house property income (say, Rs. 50,000), this loss can be set off against income from other sources like salary or business under the same head (Income from House Property).

If an individual has a short-term capital loss (Rs. 30,000) from the sale of stocks, this loss can be set off against long-term or short-term capital gains from the sale of other capital assets in the same assessment year.
A long-term capital loss (Rs. 40,000) from the sale of a house property can be set off against long-term capital gains from the sale of any other property or assets in the same assessment year.

subsections.title: Set off of Loss from One Head Against Income from Another
subsections.overview: Section 71 allows for the set-off of losses from one head of income against income from another, with specific rules for different types of income.

subsections.description: If the net result under any head of income, other than 'Capital Gains', is a loss and the assessee has no income under the 'Capital Gains' head, the loss can be set off against income from any other head, subject to provisions of this Chapter.

conditions.loss_head: Any head other than Capital Gains
conditions.income_head: Any other head of income (excluding Capital Gains)

subsections.description: If the net result under any head of income, other than 'Capital Gains', is a loss and the assessee has income under the 'Capital Gains' head, the loss may be set off against income under any head, including 'Capital Gains' (whether short-term or other capital assets), subject to provisions of this Chapter.

conditions.loss_head: Any head other than Capital Gains
conditions.income_head: Capital Gains or any other head of income

subsections.description: In case the net result of computation under the 'Profits and gains of business or profession' head is a loss and the assessee has income under the 'Salaries' head, such loss cannot be set off against the salary income.

conditions.loss_head: Profits and gains of business or profession
conditions.restriction: Cannot set off loss against salary income

subsections.description: If the net result under the 'Capital Gains' head is a loss and the assessee has income under any other head of income, the loss cannot be set off against income under the other head.

conditions.restriction: Cannot set off capital gains loss

subsections.description: If the net result under the 'Income from House Property' head is a loss, such loss can only be set off against income under the other head to the extent it does not exceed Rs. 2 lakh.

conditions.limit: Loss can be set off only up to Rs. 2 lakh against income under any other head

subsections.description: For the assessment years commencing on 1st April 1995 and 1st April 1996, the loss under the 'Income from House Property' head will first be set off as per subsections (1) and (2), and then the loss referred to in Section 71A will be set off as per that section.

conditions.set_off_sequence: First under subsections (1) and (2), then under Section 71A

examples.scenario: If an individual has a loss of Rs. 50,000 under the 'Business or Profession' head and no income under the 'Capital Gains' head, they can set off this loss against income from salary or house property under the same assessment year.
If the individual has a loss under 'Business or Profession' (Rs. 50,000) and income under 'Capital Gains' (Rs. 20,000), they can set off the business loss against the capital gains income.

If a taxpayer has a loss of Rs. 3 lakh under 'House Property' and salary income of Rs. 5 lakh, they can set off only Rs. 2 lakh of the house property loss against the salary income, as per the limit of Rs. 2 lakh.
If the individual has a capital gains loss of Rs. 30,000 but also has salary income, the capital gains loss cannot be set off against the salary income.

For the assessment years starting from 1st April 1995 to 1st April 1996, if a taxpayer has a house property loss of Rs. 1 lakh, it will first be set off under the provisions of Section 71, and then any remaining loss will be addressed under Section 71A.

subsections.title: Carry Forward and Set off of Loss from House Property
subsections.overview: Section 71B provides the provisions for carrying forward and setting off losses under the head 'Income from House Property' if they cannot be fully set off in the current year.

subsections.description: If the net result of computation under the head 'Income from House Property' is a loss and such loss cannot be or is not wholly set off against income from any other head as per Section 71, the un-settled loss will be carried forward to the next assessment year.

conditions.set_off: Loss not fully set off in the current year

subsections.description: The carried forward loss will be set off against income from house property assessable in the following assessment year.

conditions.set_off: Loss carried forward set off against house property income in subsequent years

subsections.description: The loss, if any, which remains un-set off in the following year, will be carried forward again to the next assessment year, subject to the restriction that the loss can only be carried forward for a maximum of eight years immediately succeeding the assessment year in which the loss was first computed.

examples.scenario: If an individual has a house property loss of Rs. 50,000 in the assessment year 2022-23, and this loss cannot be fully set off against any other income, the loss will be carried forward to the assessment year 2023-24. If they still do not have enough income to set off the loss, it will be carried forward again to the next year.

In the assessment year 2023-24, the individual has a house property income of Rs. 30,000. They can set off Rs. 30,000 of the loss carried forward from 2022-23 against this income, and the remaining Rs. 20,000 will be carried forward to the next assessment year.

If the individual is unable to set off the remaining Rs. 20,000 of house property loss in 2023-24, this amount will be carried forward to the assessment year 2024-25. The loss can continue to be carried forward until the assessment year 2030-31 (8 years after the original loss year).

subsections.title: Carry Forward and Set off of Business Losses
subsections.overview: Section 72 governs the carry-forward and set-off of business losses, including special provisions for losses in a speculation business and losses from businesses discontinued under specific circumstances.

subsections.description: If the net result under the head 'Profits and gains of business or profession' is a loss (except a loss from speculation business), and the loss cannot be set off against any other income as per Section 71, the un-settled loss will be carried forward to the next assessment year.

conditions.loss_head: Profits and gains of business or profession
conditions.set_off: Loss not fully set off in the current year

subsections.description: The carried forward loss will be set off against the profits and gains of any business or profession carried on by the assessee in the following assessment year.

conditions.loss_head: Profits and gains of business or profession
conditions.set_off: Loss carried forward set off against business or profession income in subsequent years

subsections.description: If the loss cannot be fully set off in the following assessment year, the remaining loss will be carried forward again to the next assessment year until it is fully set off or the 8-year carry forward limit is reached.

conditions.carry_forward_period: Loss continues to be carried forward for subsequent years until fully set off

subsections.description: If the loss arises from a business that is discontinued under Section 33B and is later re-established or revived, the loss will be carried forward and set off against the profits of the revived business for the year in which it is re-established, and for seven subsequent years.

conditions.discontinued_business: Loss from a business discontinued under Section 33B
conditions.revived_business: Loss carried forward and set off if the business is re-established or revived
conditions.set_off_period: Carried forward for seven assessment years following revival

subsections.description: If any allowance or part of it is to be carried forward under specific provisions (Sections 32 or 35), the loss will be carried forward first before applying these provisions.

conditions.allowances: Carry-forward provisions under Sections 32 or 35 apply after the loss is carried forward

subsections.description: Business losses (other than those related to discontinued businesses under Section 33B) cannot be carried forward for more than eight assessment years after the assessment year in which the loss was first computed.

conditions.carry_forward_limit: Maximum carry forward period is eight years

examples.scenario: A business has a loss of Rs. 1,00,000 in the assessment year 2022-23. The loss cannot be set off against other income and will be carried forward to the assessment year 2023-24. If there is Rs. 50,000 profit in 2023-24, Rs. 50,000 will be set off, and the remaining Rs. 50,000 will be carried forward to the next year.

In the assessment year 2024-25, the business is revived after being discontinued in 2021-22 under Section 33B. The Rs. 50,000 loss from 2021-22 will be carried forward and set off against the revived business income for the year. If any loss remains, it can be carried forward for seven subsequent assessment years.

A business incurs a loss of Rs. 2,00,000 in 2020-21. The loss cannot be fully set off in 2021-22 and is carried forward. It will continue to be carried forward for subsequent years (2022-23, 2023-24, etc.) until it is either set off or the 8-year carry-forward period expires in 2028-29.

subsections.title: Deductions in respect of Life Insurance Premium, Contributions to Provident Fund, etc.
subsections.overview: Section 80C provides for deductions from the total income of an individual or Hindu Undivided Family (HUF) for contributions to specified savings schemes, life insurance premiums, and other eligible investments. This deduction is subject to a maximum limit of ₹1.5 lakh per year.

subsections.description: Subject to the maximum limit of ₹1.5 lakh, a deduction can be claimed by an individual or HUF for the following contributions/investments made during the financial year.

conditions.description: Premium paid on life insurance policies for self, spouse, children, or parents.
Employee's contribution to the Provident Fund (PF) or Voluntary Provident Fund (VPF).
Contribution to the Public Provident Fund (PPF).
Investment in National Savings Certificates (NSC) issued by the government.
Investment in a 5-year fixed deposit with banks, recognized under 80C.
Investment in the Senior Citizens Savings Scheme (SCSS).
Contribution to the Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana (SSY) for a girl child.
Investment in tax-saving fixed deposits under section 80C with a lock-in period of 5 years.
Contribution towards ULIPs (only the premiums paid).
Tuition fees paid for the education of children, subject to certain limits.
Contribution to the NPS (additional ₹50,000 limit under section 80CCD).
Investment in post office time deposits with a minimum 5-year tenure.

subsections.description: The total deduction under Section 80C, including all eligible contributions, shall not exceed ₹1.5 lakh in a financial year, regardless of the number of eligible investments or premiums.

conditions.description: The total deduction under section 80C, including all investments, premiums, and contributions, is capped at ₹1.5 lakh per year.

subsections.description: The deduction is available only to an individual or a Hindu Undivided Family (HUF), and it is available only if the contributions are made in the specified schemes or to the specified entities.

conditions.description: Only individuals or HUFs can claim the deduction under Section 80C.

subsections.description: In the case of a self-employed individual, the deduction can also be claimed for certain expenses like tuition fees, provided they meet the other conditions of Section 80C.

conditions.description: Self-employed individuals can claim deductions for tuition fees and other eligible expenses under Section 80C.

examples.scenario: An individual contributes ₹50,000 to PPF, ₹25,000 towards Life Insurance Premium, ₹20,000 to NSC, and ₹10,000 towards tuition fees for their children. The total deduction for this individual would be ₹1,05,000 for the assessment year, which is below the ₹1.5 lakh limit.

An individual invests ₹1,30,000 in a 5-year fixed deposit, ₹20,000 in PPF, and ₹30,000 towards a ULIP. The total deduction for this individual would be ₹1.5 lakh (the maximum limit), as it exceeds the allowable limit for deductions.

An individual contributes ₹1,50,000 to NPS and ₹50,000 towards Life Insurance Premium. Since the maximum deduction limit under Section 80C is ₹1.5 lakh, only ₹1.5 lakh will be allowed as the deduction, even though more contributions were made.

provisions.provision: Section 80C is applicable only to individuals and HUFs.
provisions.effect: Corporations, firms, and other entities are not eligible for the deductions under Section 80C.

provisions.provision: Certain types of income, such as those from an undisclosed source, cannot be set off against deductions under Section 80C.
provisions.effect: Only legally taxable income is eligible for deduction under Section 80C.

additional_info.information: Section 80C deductions cannot be claimed for contributions to the Voluntary Retirement Scheme (VRS), income from non-taxable sources, or contributions that do not meet the tax department's guidelines.
Section 80C benefits are primarily designed to encourage long-term savings and investments in government-approved schemes.

subsections.title: Deductions in respect of deposits under National Savings Scheme or payment to a deferred annuity plan
subsections.overview: Section 80CCA provides deductions for individuals and Hindu Undivided Families (HUFs) for contributions made to specified National Savings Schemes or for payments to effect or keep in force a deferred annuity plan of the Life Insurance Corporation (LIC). The deduction is subject to limits and specific conditions.

subsections.description: This subsection allows a deduction for deposits made under the National Savings Scheme or payments made towards a specified deferred annuity plan of the Life Insurance Corporation (LIC).

conditions.description: The deduction is available to individuals and HUFs who deposit money in specified schemes or pay for annuity plans.

conditions.eligible_contribution: National Savings Scheme or Deferred Annuity Plan
conditions.description: The contribution must be made in schemes specified by the Central Government or towards a specified annuity plan of LIC.
The total deduction is limited to ₹20,000 for the amount deposited or paid in a given assessment year, excluding interest or bonus accrued.

increase_in_limit.description: For the assessment years commencing on 1st April 1989 and 1st April 1990, the limit was ₹30,000.
For the assessment year commencing on 1st April 1991 and subsequent years, the limit was increased to ₹40,000.

conditions.description: No deductions are allowed for amounts deposited or paid on or after 1st April 1992.

subsections.description: This subsection provides that any withdrawal from the scheme or receipt of an annuity or bonus will be treated as income and taxed in the year of withdrawal or receipt.

conditions.withdrawal_or_receipt: Withdrawals from scheme or annuity/bonus receipt
conditions.description: If any amount deposited under the scheme is withdrawn, or an annuity or bonus is received from the LIC deferred annuity plan, the whole amount will be deemed as income in the year it is received.
The provisions of this subsection do not apply to amounts received from the surrender of the LIC annuity plan if the annuity plan was surrendered before 1st October 1992.

subsections.description: This subsection applies the provisions of subsection (2) in the event of a partition of a Hindu Undivided Family (HUF) or dissolution of an association of persons, where the deduction has been allowed under subsection (1).

conditions.event: Partition of HUF or dissolution of association
conditions.description: In case of partition of an HUF or dissolution of an association of persons, the provisions of subsection (2) apply to the person receiving the income.

subsections.description: Interest accrued on deposits under the National Savings Scheme will not be chargeable to tax except in the manner specified in subsection (2).

conditions.description: Interest earned on deposits under the scheme is not taxable under this section unless withdrawn or received as per subsection (2).

subsections.description: For the purposes of this section, 'Life Insurance Corporation' refers to the LIC as defined in section 80C.

conditions.description: The term 'Life Insurance Corporation' refers to the LIC as per the definition in section 80C.

examples.scenario: An individual deposits ₹20,000 in a specified National Savings Scheme and pays ₹10,000 towards an LIC deferred annuity plan in a given assessment year. The individual can claim a deduction of ₹20,000 (the maximum allowed under section 80CCA) for that year.
An individual claims a deduction of ₹40,000 in the assessment year 1991-1992 for a deposit in a National Savings Scheme. The maximum allowed deduction for that year is ₹40,000.

An individual withdraws ₹20,000 from the National Savings Scheme in the current year, for which a deduction was previously allowed under section 80CCA. The ₹20,000 will be taxed as income in the year of withdrawal.

provisions.effect: No deductions will be allowed for amounts deposited or paid in the National Savings Scheme or LIC deferred annuity plan on or after 1st April 1992.
Any amount withdrawn or received from the schemes where a deduction was previously claimed will be treated as income and taxed accordingly.
Interest on deposits under the specified schemes will not be taxed until withdrawn or received as annuity/bonus under the conditions laid out in subsection (2).

additional_info.information: Section 80CCA applies only to individual and Hindu Undivided Families (HUFs) and is not available for companies, firms, or other entities.
This section aims to incentivize long-term savings and investments in specified government-backed schemes and LIC annuity plans.

subsections.title: Deduction in respect of investment made under Equity Linked Savings Scheme

subsections.description: Where an assessee, being an individual or Hindu undivided family, has acquired in the previous year, out of his income chargeable to tax, units of any Mutual Fund specified under clause (23D) of section 10 or of the Unit Trust of India established under the Unit Trust of India Act, 1963, under any plan formulated in accordance with such scheme as the Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, specify (Equity Linked Savings Scheme), he shall be allowed a deduction in the computation of his total income of the amount invested, not exceeding ten thousand rupees in the previous year.
subsections.exceptions: No deduction for any amount invested under this sub-section on or after the 1st day of April, 1992.

subsections.description: Where any amount invested by the assessee in the units issued under the plan formulated under the Equity Linked Savings Scheme in respect of which a deduction has been allowed is returned to him, either by repurchase of such units or on the termination of the plan, it shall be deemed to be income of the assessee of that previous year and chargeable to tax.
subsections.taxable_event: Return of investment by repurchase or plan termination
subsections.taxation: Amount is deemed as income and chargeable to tax.

subsections.description: Where a partition has taken place among the members of a Hindu undivided family or where an association of persons has been dissolved after a deduction has been allowed under sub-section (1), the provisions of sub-section (2) shall apply as if the person in receipt of income is the assessee.
subsections.exception: In case of partition of HUF or dissolution of an association of persons.

provisions.equity_linked_savings_scheme: Defined under the notification of the Central Government
provisions.exclusion_period: No deduction for amounts invested after 1st April 1992

subsections.title: Deduction in respect of contribution to certain pension funds

subsections.description: Where an assessee, being an individual, has in the previous year paid or deposited any amount out of his income chargeable to tax to effect or keep in force a contract for any annuity plan of Life Insurance Corporation of India or any other insurer for receiving pension from the fund, he shall be allowed a deduction in the computation of his total income of the whole amount paid or deposited, not exceeding ₹150,000 in the previous year.
subsections.exclusions: Excludes interest or bonus accrued or credited to the assessee's account.

subsections.description: Where any amount standing to the credit of the assessee in the pension fund, together with the interest or bonus accrued, is received by the assessee or his nominee, it shall be deemed to be income of the assessee in that previous year and chargeable to tax.

taxable_event.taxation: Amount is deemed as income and chargeable to tax.

taxable_event.event: Pension received from the annuity plan
taxable_event.taxation: Amount is deemed as income and chargeable to tax.

subsections.description: Where any amount paid or deposited by the assessee has been taken into account for the purposes of this section, a deduction with reference to such amount shall not be allowed under section 80C for any assessment year beginning on or after the 1st day of April, 2006.
subsections.exclusion_period: No deduction under section 80C for assessment years beginning on or after 1st April 2006.

provisions.qualifying_insurers: Life Insurance Corporation of India or any other insurer
provisions.non_qualifying_period: No deduction allowed under section 80C after 1st April, 2006.

subsections.title: Deduction in respect of contribution to pension scheme of Central Government

subsections.description: Deduction for individuals contributing to a notified pension scheme.
eligibility: Central Government employees (joined on or after 1st Jan 2004)

subsections.description: Omitted
Additional deduction of up to ₹50,000 for contribution to notified pension schemes, whether or not deduction under sub-section (1) is claimed.
subsections.condition: No double deduction on amount already claimed under subsection (1)

subsections.description: Deduction for employer's contribution to the pension scheme account of the employee.

finance_act_2024_update.condition: If assessee opts for section 115BAC(1A) (new tax regime)

subsections.description: Tax treatment of withdrawals or pension from the scheme.

events_taxable.event: Closure or opting out of pension scheme
events_taxable.tax: Full amount received (principal + accrued income) is taxable in year of receipt

events_taxable.event: Pension received from annuity plan post-closure
events_taxable.tax: Taxable as income in the year received

subsections.exception: If nominee receives amount on death of assessee, it is not treated as nominee's income

subsections.description: No double deduction allowed under section 80C for amounts claimed under 80CCD(1) or (1B)
subsections.note: Applicable for assessment years from 1st April 2006 onwards

subsections.description: If amount is used to purchase annuity plan in the same year, it is not deemed to be received income

explanation.salary_definition: Salary includes dearness allowance (if part of terms of employment), but excludes all other allowances and perquisites

provisions.combined_limit: Overall limit of ₹1.5 lakh under 80C + 80CCC + 80CCD(1), additional ₹50,000 available under 80CCD(1B) separately
provisions.taxability_on_withdrawal: Withdrawals or pension are taxable unless reinvested in annuity in same year

subsections.title: Limit on deductions under sections 80C, 80CCC and 80CCD(1)
subsections.description: Caps the combined deductions under specified sections to a maximum amount.
